3.text:
INTERPRETER: Welcome to Bisley, the famous
rifle ranges.

6.text:
During the years leading up to war [the First
World War],

9.text:
depots such as Bisley, and many others up
and down the country,

11.text:
were used as training depots, preparing soldiers
for service overseas.

16.text:
These depots are still used for this purpose
today.

21.text:
INTERPRETER: This is Drummer Thompson in the
2014 fighting order.

27.text:
Now, Drummer Thompson, I notice straight away
as a soldier

32.text: you don't seem to have any ammunition pouches.

34.text: A hundred rounds for me. Where are yours?

36.text:
DRUMMER THOMPSON: Yeah, I've got 120 rounds
in four magazines.

38.text: As you can see, this is a Molle pouch.

41.text:
It's Velcro, easy access - magazine out, onto
the weapon.

46.text:
You'll have full scales of ammunition in your
day sack.

49.text:
INTERPRETER: And Drummer Thompson, what about
for close-quarter work?

52.text:
We've got our bayonet - 17 inches [43cm] of
cold steel.

56.text:
DRUMMER THOMPSON: Yeah, it's made of the same
material.

58.text:
It's a lot smaller. It's a lot handier for
going in and out of buildings,

62.text: and in and out of compounds.

64.text:
And this is what we use for our close-quarter
battle,

66.text:
in case our ammunition gets expended and we
might need to thrust the insurgents.

71.text:
INTERPRETER: And if the weather isn't as nice
as it is today,

74.text: what about night time if it gets colder,

77.text:
we've got on our back the greatcoat in our
large pack.

79.text: What have you got to keep warm?

81.text: DRUMMER THOMPSON: It has changed a lot.

83.text: We'll now carry a warm kit in our day sack.

86.text:
It's probably a softie suit, like a North
Face jacket

89.text: or something like that to keep you warm.

91.text: INTERPRETER: Have you got any water on you?

94.text:
I mean we've got a pint and a half of water
in our water bottles there.

96.text: Have you got an equivalent to that?

98.text:
DRUMMER THOMPSON: Yeah, well this is a tube
here.

99.text: This is a CamelBak. It's inside the day sack.

101.text:
We still do use the water bottle, but it's
not a metal one. It's a plastic one.

106.text:
It's a bit more tactical when you're going
into battle.

108.text:
It doesn't rattle about. It doesn't rust,
as well.

111.text:
So we're using a CamelBak now. It carries
a lot more water,

114.text:
especially in the climates that we're fighting
in now.

116.text:
INTERPRETER: And, forgive me, I can't help
but notice this protrusion

120.text: appearing from above you there. What's that?

122.text:
That is a 354 Bowman radio. It's used for
speaking within the company.

127.text: It'll probably go higher to battalion level,

130.text: passing messages, being a bit tactical.

133.text:
And on here you have the Personal Role Radio
[PRR],

137.text:
which you can use for passing messages through
the section.

140.text:
So, if you're being tactical again and keeping
the noise down,

143.text:
you speak through the PRR if you want to pass
a message through the section.

146.text:
INTERPRETER: Sounds a lot more effective than
a loud voice.

148.text: Well, thank you very much, Drummer Thompson.
